guicomponents

Class GSlider

  • java.lang.Object
    • guicomponents.GComponent
      • guicomponents.GSlider
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    GConstants, Comparable<Object>, PConstants
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    GHorzSlider, GVertSlider, GWSlider

    public abstract class GSlider
extends GComponent
    Abstract class to provide a slider - GHorzSlider and GVertSlider inherit from this class.
    Author:
    Peter Lager

    • Method Detail

      • setLimits

        public void setLimits(int init,
             int min,
             int max)
        The user can change the range and initial value of the slider from the default values of range 0-100 and initial value of 50. This method ignores inertia so the effect is immediate.
        Parameters:
        init -
        min -
        max -

      • setLimits

        public void setLimits(float init,
             float min,
             float max)
        Sets the limits of the slider as float values. Converted to floats or integer depending on the type of the slider.

        Returns:
        current value

      • getValuef

        public float getValuef()
        Gets the current value of the slider. If the value type is integer then the value is rounded.

      • isValueChanging

        public boolean isValueChanging()
        Is the value changing as a result of the slider thumb being dragged with the mouse.
        Returns:
        true if value being changed at GUI

      • setValue

        public void setValue(int newValue)
        Sets the target value of the slider, if setInertia(x) has been used to implement inertia then the actual slider value will gradually change until it reaches the target value. The slider thumb is always in the right position for the current slider value.
        Note that events will continue to be generated so if this causes unexpected behaviour then use setValue(newValue, true)
        Parameters:
        newValue - the value we wish the slider to become

      • setValue

        public void setValue(int newValue,
            boolean ignoreInteria)
        The same as setValue(newValue) except the second parameter determines whether we should ignore any inertia value so the affect is immediate.
        Note if false then events will continue to be generated so if this causes unexpected behaviour then use setValue(newValue, true)
        Parameters:
        newValue - the value we wish the slider to become
        ignoreInteria - if true change is immediate

      • setValue

        public void setValue(float newValue)
        Sets the target value of the slider, if setInertia(x) has been to implement inertia then the actual slider value will gradually change until it reaches the target value. The slider thumb is always in the right position for the current slider value.
        Note that events will continue to be generated so if this causes unexpected behaviour then use setValue(newValue, true)
        Parameters:
        newValue - the value we wish the slider to become

      • setValue

        public void setValue(float newValue,
            boolean ignoreInteria)
        The same as setValue(newValue) except the second parameter determines whether we should ignore any inertia value so the affect is immediate.
        Note if false then events will continue to be generated so if this causes unexpected behaviour then use setValue(newValue, true)
        Parameters:
        newValue - the value we wish the slider to become
        ignoreInteria - if true change is immediate

      • setInertia

        public void setInertia(int inertia)
        When dragging the slider thumb rapidly with the mouse a certain amount of inertia will give a nice visual effect by trailing the thumb behind the mouse. A value of 1 (default) means the thumb is always in step with the mouse. Increasing values will increase the amount of trailing and the length of time needed to reach the final value. I have found values around 10 give quite nice effect but much over 20 and you start to loose the gliding effect due to acceleration and deacceleration.
        Parameters:
        inertia - values passed is constrained to the range 1-50.
